title: How to Make Tikoy

steps.headline: Mix the the ingredients together.
steps.description: In a bowl, combine 1.75 cups (410 ml) water and 1 cup (240 ml) sugar. Stir in the 2.5 cups (590 ml) of glutinous rice. Add the (pitted and chopped) dates if desired. You can add more or less sugar depending on your tastes.

steps.headline: Grease a cooking pan or round cake pan.
steps.description: Add grease to a round pan that will fit in a steamer. You can rub butter or oil in the pan or simply spray it with cooking spray, which will help release the rice later.

steps.headline: Pour the rice mixture in the pan.
steps.description: Use a spoon to move the rice mixture to the greased pan. Spread the mixture out with your spoon. At this point, you can sprinkle the top with sesame seeds if you'd like.

steps.headline: Cover the cake.
steps.description: If you leave the cake uncovered, water will drip down on top of it, making the top uneven. Use cheesecloth or even plastic wrap to cover the top of the cake completely.

steps.headline: Steam the rice.
steps.description: Place the cake with the pan in a steamer. Turn the heat on medium, and then leave the rice to cook. It should be done in 45 minutes to an hour. The top of the cake should be relatively firm when it's done.

steps.headline: Refrigerate for at least five hours.
steps.description: Before you can eat this dish, take it out of the pan and wrap it in wax paper or cling wrap. Refrigerate it for at least five hours or overnight. This process helps the dish set up into its solid form.

steps.headline: Cut and reheat the tikoy.
steps.description: Slice it in pieces. Cook it again before eating it. You can simply steam or microwave the tikoy until they are warmed through. Alternatively, you can fry it.

steps.headline: Cut up the tikoy.
steps.description: Take the tikoy out of the fridge. Slice it into pieces small enough to fit into a frying pan. You can cut them as wide or as skinny as you'd like them. For instance, you might cut the whole cake into six or seven pieces only.

steps.headline: Beat an egg.
steps.description: Crack an egg into a bowl big enough to dip slices in. Use a whisk or fork to thoroughly beat the egg together. You may need to use more than one egg if you have a lot of tikoy.

steps.headline: Heat up the oil.
steps.description: Pour a neutral cooking oil into a frying pan. The oil should coat the bottom of the pan. It can come up the sides a little. Place the pan over medium heat to heat the oil. A neutral cooking oil is one that doesn't have a flavor, such as vegetable oil, canola oil, or refined peanut oil.

steps.headline: Dip the tikoy.
steps.description: Dip each piece of tikoy in the beaten egg. Make sure each piece is completely coated in the egg mixture. You can leave the pieces in the egg until you place them in the frying pan.

steps.headline: Fry the tikoy.
steps.description: Pick up a piece of tikoy. Shake a bit of the egg off of it. Place it in the frying pan. If the oil is hot enough, it should sizzle a bit. If it's not hot enough, you should wait before adding more pieces. Add enough pieces to fill the pan, though don't crowd them too much.

steps.headline: Cook the tikoy lightly on each side.
steps.description: Each side will only need a minute or 2, so make sure you flip the tikoy a minute or two after placing it in the pan. Check the other side after a minute or 2. It should be lightly browned before you pull it out.

steps.headline: Pull the tikoy out of the pan.
steps.description: Line a plate with paper towels to absorb oil. As each piece finishes frying, pull it out of the pan and place it on the plate. Keep adding new pieces as you take pieces out until you've fried all of your tikoy. Serve as is when cool enough to eat.

steps.headline: Slice the tikoy and sweet potatoes.
steps.description: Slice the tikoy into even slices. For every one piece of tikoy, you'll need 2 pieces of sweet potato. Wash and peel the sweet potatoes, and then cut them into thin slices approximately the same size as the tikoy.

steps.headline: Mix up the batter.
steps.description: In a bowl, add1 large egg (beaten), 2.5 tablespoons (37 ml) flour, 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) cornstarch, 0.5 tablespoons (7.4 ml) ice water, and a dash of salt. Whisk the ingredients together until you have a smooth batter.

steps.headline: Heat up your oil.
steps.description: Place a neutral oil in a frying pan. You may need more than 1 tablespoon (15 ml) to coat the bottom of the pan. Heat the oil over medium heat until it sizzles when you put food in it. Neutral oils don't impart flavor to the food. You can try canola oil, vegetable oil, or refined peanut oil.

steps.headline: Make your sandwiches.
steps.description: Place a slice of tikoy in between 2 pieces of sweet potato. Dip the sandwich into the batter, coating it completely. Place the sandwich in the hot pan, and keep going until you've filled the pan in a single layer.

steps.headline: Fry the sandwiches.
steps.description: As you add sandwiches to the pan, check on the ones already in the pan. You can lift up an edge to check the other side. Flip the sandwich over when that when that side is lightly brown.

steps.headline: Cook until the other side is lightly brown.
steps.description: You'll likely only need a few minutes on each side, but you do want to make sure the sweet potato is cooked and the tikoy is warmed through. When they're done, take them out of the pan, and let them drain on a plate covered with paper towels.
